Reflection on The House of Us (2018)The 2018 Filipino film The House of Us, is an emotionally stirring drama that explores love, dreams, and the struggle to hold onto relationships despite life’s hardships. The movie follows the story of Primo (Daniel Padilla) and George (Kathryn Bernardo), a couple whose relationship is tested by ambition, miscommunication, and the harsh realities of life. Watching this film was a deeply emotional experience, as it delved into themes that felt incredibly real and relatable. It made me reflect on the complexities of love and the sacrifices that people make to sustain their relationships.One of the most striking aspects of The House of Us is how it captures the essence of Filipino relationships and family dynamics. The plot feels deeply Filipino because of its emphasis on love as not just an emotion but also a responsibility. Many Filipinos will see themselves in George and Primo characters who represent different perspectives on dreams and commitment. The film also highlights the idea of bahay, or home, as not just a physical structure but a place built through shared experiences and struggles. This theme resonates strongly with Filipino audiences, as family and home play a crucial role in Filipino culture. The sacrifices made by George and her struggle to balance love with self-respect mirror the reality of many Filipinos who navigate relationships while trying to improve their circumstances.The film also appears to reference other works in the romance and drama genre, particularly in how it presents its narrative and themes. For instance, it shares similarities with One More Chance (2007), another Filipino film that explores second chances in love and the consequences of choices in a relationship. Like One More Chance, The House of Us portrays raw emotions and the difficult path toward forgiveness and reconciliation. Additionally, it takes inspiration from classic romance tropes found in both literature and film, such as the idea of lovers growing apart due to personal ambitions but later finding a way to reconnect. These references are used effectively to enhance the film’s storytelling, making it feel familiar yet fresh.

"The Hows of Us" is a Philippine romantic drama that left me with a combination of emotions – from the euphoria of first love to the heartache of its inevitable problems and the heartwarming process of reunion. The movie explores the intricacies of relationships, emphasizing the fluctuations that come with loving, pursuing ambitions, and developing as a person. What really makes "The Hows of Us" work is its strong Filipino identity. The movie features recognizable social dynamics, family values, and the emphasis on relationships in Filipino culture. The location, a warm and inviting home that George inherited from his late grandmother, is symbolic of the strong sense of family and tradition found in Filipino society. The struggle of the characters with family expectations, financial burdens, and the chase for their dreams is very relatable to most Filipinos.The movie's own Filipino touch can be seen in its characters, dialogue, and storyline. The characters themselves sound and look distinctly Filipino, as their body language, reactions, and dialogue all resonate well with the local population. The fact that the plot dwells so much on family, tradition, and dealing with the demands of society lends the movie a characteristically Filipino tone. "The Hows of Us" is a movie that resonates with Filipino experiences, capturing the spirit of love, family, and self-discovery in a cultural setting that is both familiar and endearing.

What makes The Hows of Us distinctly Filipino is its reflection of Filipino values and culture. The film portrays the importance of family, sacrifice, and resilience — traits deeply embedded in Filipino society. The characters' constant balancing act between personal ambition and family responsibilities mirrors the lives of many Filipinos who prioritize loved ones over personal desires. The use of Taglish and the depiction of everyday life in the Philippines further ground the narrative in the local context. The story also touches on the "tiis-ganda" or "tiis-hirap" mindset, where characters endure hardships in the hope of a better future, a common theme in Filipino storytelling.Beyond the romance, the film resonates because it speaks to the struggles of young people chasing dreams while navigating love and financial difficulties. The heartfelt dialogue, picturesque cinematography, and moving soundtrack all contribute to its emotional appeal. The Hows of Us not only captures the highs and lows of relationships but also serves as a reflection of the resilience and hope that define the Filipino spirit.

The Hows of Us (2018) is a Filipino romantic drama film directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina and starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla. The film tells the story of Primo and George, a young couple who dream of a future together but struggle with the realities of love, ambition, and personal growth. Plot SummaryGeorge and Primo are college sweethearts who move in together, hoping to build a life around their shared dreams. However, their relationship is tested as Primo's pursuit of a music career leads to disappointments, while George, who is more practical, begins to question their future. The movie explores how love can be both a source of strength and a challenge when personal ambitions collide with relationships. Review As a student, the film resonates deeply because it highlights themes of ambition, sacrifice, and personal growth—issues many young people face. The story is realistic, showing that love alone is not always enough to sustain a relationship. Kathryn Bernardo delivers a heartfelt performance as George, portraying the struggles of someone torn between love and self-respect. Daniel Padilla, as Primo, effectively shows the frustration of chasing dreams while holding onto a relationship. The cinematography and soundtrack add to the emotional impact, making key scenes more powerful. The script is well-written, with dialogues that capture real-life struggles. One of the most relatable aspects of the film is the message about knowing when to hold on and when to let go—a lesson relevant not only in relationships but also in personal aspirations. Conclusion Overall, “The Hows of Us” is a must-watch, especially for students who are navigating love, career goals, and personal growth. It teaches the importance of communication, compromise, and self-worth. The movie is emotional, thought-provoking, and inspiring, making it a great film for young audiences.

‘The Hows of Us’ is a 2018 Filipino romantic drama directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina, starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla. As the movie goes, we follow Primo and George, a couple who dreamed of building a life together but struggled with the realities of love, career aspirations, and personal growth. As their relationship faces a lot of challenges along with their career progress, they must decide whether to keep fighting for their love or let go for their own individual happiness. The movie offers a deep and emotional look into love, sacrifices, and the struggles of young couples trying to build life together.The movie brought a mix of emotions, joy, frustration, heartbreak, and hope. It was easy to connect with the struggles of Primo and George, making their story feel real and authentic. There were moments of kilig (romantic excitement), especially in the early stages of their relationship, but as they grew together conflicts arose, I felt the pain and frustration of their struggles. The film’s emotional depth made it hard not to sympathize with both characters, especially George, who had to make difficult choices for her standing in the relationship and the stake of her future. The ending will leave you with an emotional strain that is bittersweet yet satisfying impact.Their dialogue felt natural and realistic, blending Filipino and English like everyday conversations. Their emotional exchanges, especially during conflicts, made them more authentic and relatable. The movie reflects Filipino culture through family values, sacrifices, and dreams. The setting, character names, and struggles with career and relationships make it deeply relatable to Filipino audiences. For me, a ‘Hugot’ refers to heartfelt deep feelings of emotional lines drawn from personal experiences. A memorable hugot line from the movie is when George said to Primo“Matalino akong tao eh! Pero ba’t pagdating sayo? Ba’t sayo ang tanga-tanga ko.” This captures the vulnerability of a person to love that she feels smart in life but weak when it comes to her own emotions.In conclusion, ‘The Hows of Us’ is more than just a film, it is a reflection of real-life relationships and the challenges that come with love and personal growth. The emotions it expresses, the realistic dialogues, and the distinctly Filipino elements make it a compelling and heartfelt movie. It beautifully captures the essence of hugot, making it relatable to anyone who has experienced love and heartbreak. The film serves as a reminder for all of us that when loving someone, no matter how deep, and you want to fight it out, understand that and sometimes, letting go to something will truly grow.

"The Hows of Us" is a cinematic experience that masterfully navigates viewers through a whirlwind of emotions, making it a truly impactful film. The movie's ability to rapidly shift emotions is a testament to its storytelling effectiveness, as it delves into the intricate complexities of relationships and the profound emotional struggles of its characters. This resonates deeply with Filipinos, who are renowned for their strong family bonds and expressive nature.The film's conclusion, while satisfying, left me empathizing with George's reaction. It's challenging to internalize emotions when others expect you to remain composed and manage your daily life without showing any signs of distress. This societal expectation can be overwhelming, as it pressures individuals to maintain a facade of being okay, even when they're struggling to cope with their emotions. The movie highlights this struggle, making it relatable and thought-provoking for viewers.

"The Hows of Us," starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla, is a Filipino romantic drama that explores the complexities of long-term relationships, showcasing the highs and lows of love, dreams, and sacrifice. The Hows of Us, a Filipino film that tells the story of a young couple, was portrayed by Kathryn Bernardo as (George) and Daniel Padilla as (Primo). This film reflects the importance of balancing dreams and reality. A meaningful movie that combined drama and romance, especially the tragedies of love and life that are ready to endure everything, even to the point of losing everything, for the sake of love. This film teaches us that we need to have self-love, make ourselves a priority first, and then anything else, because at the end what you have is yourself.

The film tackles important themes such as personal growth, the fear of change, and the difficulty of maintaining a relationship through evolving circumstances. It emphasizes the importance of communication, compromise, and self-discovery in love. The movie suggests that it's okay to grow apart as individuals, but it’s the way you handle that growth together that matters most.

The movie "The Hows of Us" portrays the sacrifices one makes for love and dreams. this is a story of a couple who is struggling to balance their ambitions and dreams due to personal and passion differences. Primo is deeply passionate about music and dreams of making a name in the industry, while George is devoted to helping people medically. However, the movie left me disappointed by how George was willing to sacrifice everything including her medical school exam just…

The movie feels Filipino because of its setting, culture, and family dynamics. The scenes are set in a typical Filipino home, and the storyline revolves around themes like family expectations, perseverance, and love—things that are deeply important in Filipino culture. Even the soundtrack and dialogue make it more relatable, capturing the essence of a real Filipino relationship. Overall, The Hows of Us is an emotional and heartwarming film that reflects the realities of love and sacrifice in a Filipino context.

The movie The Hows of Us made me feel deep sympathy for George and Primo. They love each other, but they struggle to carry all the burdens and problems they are facing. George grows tired because, while pursuing her dreams, she also works hard to pay the bills and make ends meet. Primo, on the other hand, has passion, but he cannot achieve his dreams. Their love is strong, but their challenges test their relationship, making it difficult for them to stay together despite their efforts.

The movie is about a young couple who is trying to explore or keep their relationship while maintaining to pursue their dreams individually. For me, this movie is very relatable. I know this happens a lot to couples, this movie shows us reality. In a relationship, there is always one person who love the other . Even when one already wants to break up or leave the relationship, there is still this little chance that maybe their partner will change…

It’s a great movie, but I didn’t like it. I get the message that maturity is needed for a relationship to work, but do I think Primo is a good match for George? Absolutely not. I understand that time can help us grow, but do you really need growth to realize you’ve ruined your partner's career and become a burden while they sacrifice everything just to meet your basic needs? Even after Primo came back, he needed another breakdown from George to realize the damage he caused couldn’t be fixed with sweet gestures or “pa-pogi” moments. No relationship is perfect, but the situations here were a little difficult for me, and it lacked empathy until the very end. That was a huge red flag. George deserved better!!!also, the ending was so cliché, I wanted George to choose herself and focus on her own growth instead of returning to Primo. She had so much potential on her own, and the movie missed that opportunity. I think they’re better off apart, because sometimes maturity is realizing the person you love might be better off without you. I wish they had stayed on good terms instead of jumping back into a relationship. They should’ve taken it slow. The ending really didn’t sit right with me huhu – again, George deserved better as for my additional prompts, I don’t think romance films are a waste if the leads don’t end up together. A good film is about character growth, not just staying together. Sometimes, not being together is the more mature choice. In *The Hows of Us*, I think it would’ve been better if George didn’t go back to Primo. Their personal growth was more important than just a happy ending. So, no, the movie wasn’t a waste of time for me  there are scenes naman na nakakakilig kaya worth the watch parin

I chose to watch "The Hows of Us" by KathNiel because it shows the reality that not all relationships are happy and exciting. But there comes a time when it gets tiring. There’s a scene that make me laugh because in real life, we have friends who will tell you an advice like “ beh, iwan mo na yan wag mong sayangin sarili mo jan” hahahahaha shempre you're so marupok, you won't listen. The lesson you get from this movie is that you need balance in love. Give yourself time and love, and do the same for your partner and the people in your life. Make yourself a priority because you can't truly support others if you're lacking in yourself. It's literally in our culture to love fiercely even when it's hard. When it comes to the actors, KathNiel did a solid job conveying real emotions and scenes. It was easy to understand. The film The Hows of Us portrays the struggles of sustaining a long-term relationship, emphasizing that love is not just about happiness and romance but also involves challenges and imperfections. One particularly emotional scene is when Georgina expresses her struggles to Primo , capturing the reality of love—that it requires sacrifice, commitment, and mutual understanding between partners.

The movie captures the ups and downs of a young couple, as they navigate their relationship while pursuing their individual dreams. Their journey feels very relatable, especially to young Filipinos who understand the balance between love, ambition, and family. The movie made me feel a mix of emotions. It shows the challenges that come with love and how it isn't always perfect, but with effort, relationships can grow stronger.One of the most Filipino things in the movie is the constant tug between career aspirations and family responsibilities. In Filipino culture, there’s often pressure to take care of family, and that can sometimes affect personal dreams. This is shown in the movie, where George has to make decisions about her future, while Primo also faces challenges in his own career. It's a situation many Filipino families can relate to because of the importance of close family ties.Overall, it's a heartfelt, emotional film that highlights the Filipino experience of balancing love, career, and family. It speaks to the heart of what it means to be a Filipino—where family is everything, and love, no matter how complicated, always holds a special place. The movie feels real, grounded in Filipino culture, and is something I believe many can connect to.

For anyone who has ever fought hard for a relationship, The Hows of Us will hit home. Whether you’ve had "the one that got away" or "the one who desperately tried to stay," the film captures the bittersweet reality of love—sometimes, it’s about holding on, and other times, it’s about knowing when to let go.The Hows of Us is more than just a love story—it’s a reflection of how relationships evolve and how love, at its core, is a choice we make every day.

The Hows of Us* (2018) is an affecting study in love, sacrifice, and the trials of maturing together—or apart—through time. Directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina and starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla, the film tracks Primo and George, a couple whose erstwhile brilliant future is gradually extinguished by ambition, disillusionment, and the harsh realities of adulthood.What is particularly Filipino about *The Hows of Us* is its visceral emotional center, one that speaks to the very notion of *hugot*—that bare, gut-level pull of emotion oftentimes associated with individual histories of love and heartbreak. Primo's quest for his ambitions, with George lugging the burden of prudence, reflects a common Filipino dynamic in which aspiration and responsibility tend to war against one another. The fact that *pamilya* is an important consideration in their choices also makes the story more rooted in Filipino culture, reaffirming the way that love is seldom just between two individuals, but wrapped up in family obligations. The movie also toys with the concept of *sayang*—that aching, lingering sorrow when love fails because of everything. Although *The Hows of Us* provides closure, it dwells on the heartache of nearly losing someone, so it is understandable to anyone who has ever clung to love a little too long. It does not merely pose the question of whether love is worth fighting for, but whether love by itself is ever sufficient.Would the life of Primo and George have been the same if they were not in the Philippines? Maybe not. The cultural significance of *kapit* (holding on), *tiis* (patience), and the anticipation of *pagtatagal* (enduring love) influence their journey. Deep down, *The Hows of Us* is not simply a love story—it is a testament to what it is to love as a Filipino.

The Hows of Us is a beautifully written film that captures the complexities of love, commitment, and personal growth in a long-term relationship. The screenplay is deeply emotional and relatable, presenting a realistic portrayal of how love isn't just about grand romantic gestures but also about patience, sacrifice, and navigating life's uncertainties together.As filipino Madami sa atin ang gaya ni George. Na sinasabi natin na pagod na tayo, na umalis na sila sa buhay natin. Pero deep inside, ang gusto natin ay habulin tayo at higit sa lahat ay wag tayo iwan kahit anong pag papaalis natin sakanila. Dahil nga pagod lang tayo at kailangan lang ng konting pahinga. What makes the film so well-written is its ability to balance raw emotions with meaningful dialogue, showing how relationships evolve over time. Ithighlights the struggles of chasing dreams while maintaining a relationship, the resentment that can build when one person feels left behind, and the challenge of deciding whether love is enough to keep two people together.

The Hows of Us feels distinctly "Filipino" to me, especially in how Kath, despite being busy with her studies and preparing for an important exam—on top of dealing with the stress brought by Daniel—still chose to care for him, even at the cost of her own well-being. It reflects the selflessness we often show for our loved ones. As Filipinos, we tend to compromise on things that matter to us, but when it comes to the people we love, we willingly make sacrifices.

I have already watched this movie multiple times, from cinema to netflix, yet it does not change the excitement and kilig I feel everytime I watch it. The kilig when Primo & George's relationship was just starting, the happiness I felt with them when their relationship worked for years, and also the anger when things started to go downhill and Primo chose to be selfish, self-centered, immature and impractical with the decisions he made which greatly affected George's mental health and career because she put Primo on top of her priority, especially over her exam. Truly, love can make people do crazy things, not thinking and considering the consequences that comes with it. The movie also portrayed the importance of maintaining the teamwork in the relationship, the "doing things together" even with the smallest thing. Most importantly, the show is an eye opener of the beauty of growing, even if it means the need of growing apart. The beauty of exploring life outside your comfort zone, facing your fears and conquering what the world has for you outside your shell. After all, if things are really meant to happen, no matter how many turns, delays or challenges you both face in life, fate will have its own way of bringing you back to each other's life. At that time, you both are grown up, able to make decisions that also considers your partner and has a different perspectives in life, making you love each other in the right way—the way you both deserve to love and to be loved. Just like how fate brought back Primo and George together after years of not having communication, both shared different life realizations and lessons that made them who they were when they met again. One thing just did not change after years of being apart, the fact that they will always be the missing part of each other, the one that will complete the empty and dull space of their lives.

"The Hows of Us" is a poignant exploration of love, sacrifice, and the complexities of sustaining a long-term relationship. Unlike many conventional romance films that often present fairy-tale endings and idealized narratives, this movie authentically examines the tough choices couples must face, especially the delicate balance between pursuing personal dreams and nurturing a commitment to a loved one.The palpable chemistry between Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla enhances the emotional depth of their characters’ journey. The film expertly integrates "hugot" lines—expressions that resonate with real-life experiences of heartbreak and hope—adding a layer of relatability that connects with viewers on a personal level.A defining aspect of this film is its depiction of Filipino values, particularly the emphasis on perseverance, the significance of family, and the necessity of shared responsibilities. These principles are fundamental to Filipino relationships, allowing George and Primo’s struggles to resonate even more profoundly with the audience. Their story intertwines themes of survival and mutual support, grounding their experience in a relatable reality.Moreover, "The Hows of Us" leaves a lasting impression by conveying that love encompasses far more than grand gestures or passionate romances. It illustrates that true love often requires hard work, compromise, and a steadfast commitment to one another—especially during challenging times. The film ultimately serves as a poignant reminder that enduring love is forged not only through moments of joy but also amid shared struggles and unwavering dedication to each other.

"The Hows of Us" pinatunayan sa atin na walang patutunguhan ang isang relasyon kung may isa sa inyo ang makasarili. Primo is egotistical, too ambitious, and self-centered. I understand; he wants to provide for their future and be successful, but in the end, he loses. He had forgotten the concept of relationship. He was so focused on his ambition that he forgot he had a partner who needed him.Conversely, George shows that when a woman falls in love, she is prepared to jeopardize everything to validate her worthiness.Every relationship has its own unique set of stories, problems, and dreams. However, we all know that we all desire the same ending: "Happily ever after". LOVE is more than just passion or practicality; it is about mutual respect, understanding, and compromise. Primo becomes more open and supportive of George's artistic ambitions, seeing that her dreams are an integral part of who she is. He learns to be more open about his personal needs and worries, rather than focusing solely on providing for their future.George, in turn, learns to understand that partnerships involve effort, and that love is more than just beautiful gestures; it is also about overcoming obstacles together. She understands that they may still dream together, but they must learn to compromise and talk openly. In the film's last minutes, they are seen heading forward together, hand in hand, with a fresh sense of dedication to one other. While their relationship may never be perfect, they have matured and learnt to negotiate their differences in a healthier manner, indicating a bright future. The film, demonstrating that love necessitates ongoing effort, understanding, and adaptation—all of which Primo and George are now prepared to accept.

The Hows of Us movie this film explores the highs and lows of love, the importance of communication, and the challenges of navigating life's uncertainties together.The film's strength lies in its realistic portrayal of relationship struggles. It doesn't shy away from showing the messy, sometimes painful, aspects of love, including infidelity, resentment, and the difficulty of letting go."Mahal kita, pero hindi na kaya ng puso ko." This line perfectly to express the heartbreaking reality of a relationship reaching its breaking point, where love persists but the emotional burdens becomes unbearable.

The Hows of Us is a deeply emotional and thought-provoking film that explores the complexities of love, dreams, and sacrifice. Directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina and starring Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla, the film follows the journey of Primo and George—two young lovers whose relationship is tested by ambition, failure, and personal growth.One of the strongest aspects of the film is how Filipino it feels, from its themes of family expectations to the struggle of chasing dreams while maintaining relationships. Primo, an aspiring musician, embodies the passion and persistence of many Filipinos pursuing creative careers, while George represents the pragmatic side—someone who wants stability and security in life. Their struggles resonate with many, especially those who have had to choose between love and personal aspirations.The dialogue also reflects the way many Filipinos speak, blending English and Filipino naturally. There are several hugot moments—lines filled with raw emotion that hit deep—especially during George and Primo’s confrontations. One of the most memorable lines, “Pagod na pagod na ako!” encapsulates the exhaustion of fighting for a love that no longer feels equal.The film also plays with the idea of sayang—a relationship that could have worked if circumstances had been different. While it does not completely follow the tragic romance trope, it still presents a mature take on love: that loving someone isn’t just about passion but also about effort, compromise, and timing.

The Hows of Us is a story of love, forgiveness, understanding, and struggle. I had heartbreak, happiness, and butterflies in my stomach while watching the film. Their relationship has the feel of a rollercoaster ride. On certain days, they both feel so happy and loved. The following day, however, their relationship is at its worst, with both of them detesting one another. It is true that challenges are an essential aspect of a relationship in order to strengthen it. But when Primo and George make the decision to part ways, they become so much better. In the film, George always shows concern and prioritizes her family, reflecting Filipino culture. They are always present, even in her dreams. Being in a relationship, their experience helped me understand that love is unpredictable. In certain situations in life, love would not be sufficient; therefore, you would be unaware of what would happen to you in the future.

"The Hows of Us" is a beautifully written film that takes viewers on an emotional rollercoaster. I appreciate how realistically it portrays a love that isn't always perfect; it shows a relationship enduring difficulties.The film's Filipino essence is embodied in George's unwavering support for Primo. She silently bears the weight of their struggles, believing in his potential for success. Despite her exhaustion, she remains supportive, only voicing her burden when she can no longer endure it. Her immense sacrifice exemplifies the Filipino concept of "tanga sa pag-ibig", yet her actions are entirely understandable, stemming from her deep love and faith in Primo.I loved how each character's growth leads to self-discovery, particularly Primo's understanding of sacrifice and his ability to overcome his pride.Primo and George's journey isn't perfect; it demands significant sacrifices and overcoming numerous challenges. Nonetheless, the film emphasizes the importance of individual and couple growth. It teaches us that relationships don't stifle dreams; rather, shared dreams foster growth. Sacrifice is inherent in making a relationship work, and ultimately, "The Hows of Us" advocates for mutual support rather than burdening each other. Choosing to love someone means accepting them despite life's hardships.

This movie " The House of Us" reflect the filipino way of how to deal when it comes to love, a selfless love. Where ready to endured the sufferings and pains for the sake of the loved ones. The famous thing in Filipinos was giving the value to every detail they received from the family. Also, the most popular thing that had the Filipinos was music. It beautifully captures themes of love, sacrifice, and ambition, reflecting how many Filipinos hold onto relationships despite growing differences.The film is undeniably good—strong performances, great chemistry, and emotional storytelling make it worth watching. However, it also highlights red flags like poor communication and unresolved issues, which shouldn’t be romanticized. While the movie shows the value of fighting for love, it blurs the line between healthy commitment and staying in a relationship that might no longer be right.Overall, The Hows of Us is a touching film that reflects Filipino values on love but also reminds us that not all love stories are perfect—or should be.

One of the lesson of hows of us is Love is not enough to keep a relationship strong, sometimes they still had problems. love needs patience, understanding and effort. Choosing yourself is also important, George sacrifice a lot for Primo, but she realized she was losing herself. this shows that we should never forget our own dreams and happiness for someone else. Not all relationships last forever. even though George and primo still love each other, sometimes letting go is the best choice for both people, after all their struggles found each other again at the right time, like for everyone we should not rush love. if something is meant for us, it will come at the right time. this movie teaches us that love should help us grow, not hold us back, its okay to love someone but we should never lose ourselves in the process.

In the 2018 Filipino love drama The Hows of Us, Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla play the lead roles. It centers on Primo and George, a couple whose relationship is put to the strain by their conflicting goals—Primo's difficulties as a musician and George's need for security—and is directed by Cathy Garcia-Molina.The film highlights the strong chemistry between the leads and features outstanding performances, particularly from Kathryn Bernardo. It is extremely relatable since it examines themes of love, sacrifice, and second chances. It's among the top KathNiel films because of its profound emotional content, excellent directing, and breathtaking photography.

After re-watching this movie (the hows of us), I resonated in so many ways. This movie is a reflection on personal growth, the need for compromise, and sometimes painful process of maturing within a relationship. I think Kathryn especially owned this film after showcasing such true and raw emotions whenever there are those bawling scenes with Daniel that was either because of happiness, anger or grief. And Daniel somehow became less of the typical cool and proud character he has portrayed in the past and he showed that he can also shine in his quiet, turned well-mannered character who isn’t argumentative or proud.The portrayal of George and Primo’s love has not been grand. In fact, the turn of events in their love story were unflattering. There’s nothing to be proud of when your boyfriend is broke but still can’t swallow his pride because he is too inflexible to do something else aside from his music. There’s nothing to be proud of that George is devoted to a person who kept proving to her and to other people that he’s just a no good. It’s hard that they’ve reached the ultimate slump in their relationship and they have to realize that it’s no longer healthy to stay in that relationship. Most definitely, it is silly and true for us humans, that we only find ourselves and make time to right our wrongs when we’ve lost the most important thing in our lives.As for the hugot, I can't forget when Kat said "Pagod na pagod na pagod na pagod na ko", we all feel this whenever we feel that we're the only one who carries the relationship. The movie shines in its portrayal of the struggles that come with balancing love and ambition, and it underscores the reality that love may not always be enough if you don’t grow together as individuals.

One of the lesson of hows of us is Love is not enough to keep a relationship strong, sometimes they still had problems. love needs patience, understanding and effort. Choosing yourself is also important, George sacrifice a lot for Primo, but she realized she was losing herself. this shows that we should never forget our own dreams and happiness for someone else. Not all relationships last forever. even though George and primo still love each other, sometimes letting go is the best choice for both people, after all their struggles found each other again at the right time, like for everyone we should not rush love. if something is meant for us, it will come at the right time. this movie teaches us that love should help us grow, not hold us back, its okay to love someone but we should never lose ourselves in the process.

"The Hows of Us" is such an amazing and inspiring movie that I would recommend to everyone. It clearly shows the strength of love despite life's challenges, showing that love endures, especially for those we cherish most. Therefore, we must learn to understand one another, as understanding is the ultimate strategy for successful and healthy relationships. Reflecting on the film, both characters ultimately realize the mistakes of their judgments. The girl didn't understand what the boy was going through in his family (he was compared to his other siblings with a descent jobs, unlike him. Making him the person he didn't want to be). While the boy failed to deeply understand and consider the girl's feelings (He reacted to her words without fully understanding them more deeply). The film highlights the importance of communication, offering insight into the characters' struggles and emphasizing the need for mutual support to overcome life's ups and downs. We must remember that we need each other's support, and no one can provide that better than someone who truly understands us. No matter what happens, always communicate, consider each other's feelings, don't give up easily, and it's okay to rest, but not to give up. This film is a beautiful filipino masterpiece, showcasing that love can last if both partners understand each other and always choose to find solutions instead of giving up. It realistically portrays love's challenges, and its Filipino perspective, where it highlights that love isn't just about romance; it involves choosing between personal dreams and commitment to a loved one. The sacrifices made, the perseverance shown—these are hallmarks of the Filipino spirit, making this film a truly recognizable and resonant portrayal of Filipino life and values.

Reflection on The Hows of UsThe Hows of Us is a deeply emotional film that resonated with me on many levels. It made me feel a mix of sadness, hope, and pride, as it told a story of love and perseverance that felt both universal and uniquely Filipino. The struggles of George and Primo, balancing love with personal growth and ambition, struck a chord because they reflect real-life challenges many young couples face, especially in the Philippines.What makes the movie distinctly Filipino is its emphasis on family, sacrifice, and resilience. George’s deep sense of responsibility, not just for herself but for her shared dreams with Primo, mirrors the Filipino value of bayanihan or communal support. The setting, with its familiar homes, vibrant streets, and local culture, immediately evokes the everyday life of many Filipinos. Even the characters’ names, George and Primo, feel relatable and authentic, reflecting how Filipino names often carry simplicity and charm.The way the characters look and speak also feels Filipino. Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla embody a natural, down-to-earth aesthetic that resonates with Filipino audiences. Their dialogue, filled with a mix of English and Filipino (Taglish), reflects how many Filipinos communicate. The humor, the dramatic expressions, and even the moments of silence between them capture the essence of how Filipinos connect and express themselves in relationships.The plot itself feels inherently Filipino because it revolves around themes of sacrifice, enduring hardship, and chasing dreams despite adversity. Primo’s struggle to pursue his passion for music, even as it strains his relationship with George, reflects the Filipino spirit of pangarap (dreaming big) and the tension it creates within relationships and families. George’s ultimate decision to prioritize herself is a powerful message about self-love, but it is also rooted in the idea that love requires strength and compromise—values deeply embedded in Filipino culture.This story couldn’t have unfolded the same way if the characters weren’t Filipino. The cultural backdrop, their ways of handling conflict, and their resilience are shaped by the Filipino way of life. The characters’ dreams, their struggles with finances, and their deep connections to family and tradition are experiences many Filipinos can relate to.The film also nods to other works in Filipino cinema, especially the tradition of romantic dramas that deal with heartbreak and redemption. Its themes are universal, yet the Filipino flavor in its storytelling, dialogue, and values make it stand out. On the other hand, The Hows of Us has become iconic in itself, often referenced in memes and conversations about modern relationships in the Philippines. Lines like “I’m so tired” have become symbolic of emotional struggles, and the movie has been hailed as a modern classic in Filipino romance films.In conclusion, The Hows of Us is more than a love story; it’s a reflection of Filipino culture and values. It speaks to the heart of what it means to love, to dream, and to grow—both as individuals and as a couple—while staying true to one’s roots. It’s a film that Filipinos can see themselves in, and that’s what makes it so impactful.

Watching The Hows of Us felt like going through a rollercoaster of emotions—one moment, you're swooning over Primo and George’s sweet moments, and the next, you’re feeling the weight of their struggles. This film is more than just a love story; it’s a reflection of real-life relationships, the sacrifices people make for love, and the painful reality that sometimes, love alone isn’t enough. :)One of the most striking things about The Hows of Us is how undeniably Filipino it feels. The story revolves around dreams, sacrifices, and the struggle between love and personal ambition—things that many Filipinos, especially the younger generation, can deeply relate to. George and Primo’s relationship isn’t the sugarcoated romance we often see in mainstream rom-coms. It’s raw, messy, and full of the kind of emotional punches that make you reflect on your own relationships, whether they’re romantic, familial, or even personal aspirations that require difficult choices.The film also captures a very Filipino dynamic—the expectation to endure, to stay, to fight for love even when things get unbearably hard. It highlights the cultural sentiment of “sayang” when relationships don’t work out, as if every failed relationship is a lost investment rather than a lesson. The setting, the way the characters talk, the family pressures, and even the concept of diskarte in life and love all feel so close to home.As for hugot, The Hows of Us is full of it. George’s monologues about feeling exhausted from carrying the relationship on her own hit hard. Primo’s struggle between chasing his dreams and being a responsible partner is a reality many Filipinos face. The line “Pagod na pagod na ako” is something that lingers, because haven’t we all, at some point, felt drained from fighting for something that no longer feels fair? Do romance films feel “sayang” when the leads don’t end up together? Not necessarily. But in this case, the ending was both satisfying and realistic—love isn’t just about the big gestures, it’s about growth, timing, and the willingness to compromise. The Hows of Us gives us a hopeful ending, but not before reminding us that love isn’t just about staying; it’s about choosing each other despite the hardships, over and over again.

The Hows of Us is a heartfelt portrayal of love, sacrifice, and the struggles of maintaining a long-term relationship. Unlike typical romance films, it delves into the reality of choosing between personal dreams and staying with someone you love. The chemistry between Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla makes the emotional weight of their story feel raw and relatable, especially with the film’s natural use of hugot lines that reflect real-life heartbreak and hope. What makes the film distinctly Filipino is its emphasis on perseverance, family, and shared responsibilities values deeply embedded in Filipino relationships. George and Primo’s struggles are not just about love but also about survival, making their story feel grounded and authentic. The film leaves a lasting impact by showing that love is not just about grand gestures but about fighting for each other even when things get difficult.

The Hows of Us stands out for its emotional depth well executed performances from the both lead actors, and it realistic portrayal of the ups and downs of love. Kathryn and Daniel chemistry is undeniable making it one of the notable romantic films in the Philippines cinema. What I really like about this movie is that it portray many aspects of the realities that many couples face in real life. The film explore the complexities of a long term relationship, highlighting how love alone is not always enough to sustain it. The struggles that primo and George face reflect the challenges that many couples experience such as personal growth and dreams. Both the characters have personal goals and dreams, and throughout the movie, they must navigate how to prioritize their individual aspirations while maintaining their relationship. This mirrors how many couples struggle with balancing their personal ambitions and the dynamics of being in a partnership.

"The Hows of Us," a KathNiel starrer, isn't just another romantic comedy; it's a poignant exploration of love, commitment, and the messy realities of long-term relationships. Primo and George, the film's central characters, navigate the highs and lows of their shared dreams, facing challenges that range from career setbacks to family disapproval. The movie cleverly interweaves their present struggles with flashbacks of their blossoming romance, offering a compelling look at how time and circumstance can impact even the strongest bonds. While the film certainly delivers the kilig moments KathNiel fans expect, it also delves into deeper emotional territory, prompting viewers to reflect on their own relationships and the sacrifices love often demands.Personally, "The Hows of Us" resonated with me because it portrayed a relationship that felt real and relatable. It wasn't a fairytale romance; it was a story about two people trying to make it work, even when things got tough. I appreciated the film's honesty in depicting the arguments, the insecurities, and the moments of doubt that are inevitable in any long-term partnership. It reminded me that love isn't always sunshine and rainbows; it's also about navigating storms together and choosing to stay, even when it's hard. The film's exploration of dreams, both individual and shared, also struck a chord. It highlighted the importance of supporting each other's aspirations, even when they diverge from the initial plan.On social media, I'd caption a still from the movie with something like, "Love isn't about finding someone you can live with, it's about finding someone you can't live without... even when they drive you crazy. #TheHowsOfUs #Hugot #KathNiel #RelateMuch". Another post could feature a picture of George crying with the caption, "Sometimes, love means letting go. But sometimes, it also means fighting harder. Which one is the real deal? #TheHowsOfUs #LoveLessons #KathNiel #DeepThoughts". These "hugot" lines capture the emotional core of the film and tap into the universal experiences of love, loss, and the complexities of human relationships.The film's plot twist revolves around the true meaning of the "hows" in the title. While the audience initially assumes it refers to the practicalities of a relationship (how to live together, how to manage finances, etc.), the twist reveals a deeper meaning. It turns out that the "hows" refer to the different ways people love. Primo's love language is acts of service and providing for George, while George expresses her love through words and emotional support. The film highlights how these different "hows" can sometimes clash, leading to misunderstandings and hurt feelings. The resolution comes when they finally understand and appreciate each other's unique ways of loving, realizing that love isn't just about grand gestures but also about recognizing and valuing the small, everyday expressions of affection.
bobo ni primo.

Ang kwento ay nag simula ng si George at Primo na sa umpisa ay mag kamag aral na nagkaibigan. Ng mag kolehiyo si George ay tumuloy sa pag aaral ng medisina habang si primo itunuloy na isang maging sikat na musikero sa pamamagitan ng pag babanda. Sila ay nanirahan sa loob ng iisang bahay habang sabay na nangagarap ng magandang buhay at nangako sa isat isa na susuportahan at isat isa. Lumipas ang mga araw ang pangarap ni Primo na sumikat bilang isang musikero ay di nag tagumpay. Dahil dito nag iba ang kanyang pag uugali hanggang sa umabot na pati ang kanyang mga kaibigan at kabanda ay pinili na lumayo sa kanya. Habang si Primo nag bago, si George ay patuloy na iniintindi at minamahal si primo kahit ang kapalit nito ay ang kanyang pang sariling kasiyahan at pangarap . Sa kasamaang palad lahat ng bagay ay may hangganan ng si George ay napuno na sa ikinikilos at ginagawa ni Primo kaya naman kahit labag sa loob pinaalis ni Goerge si Primo sa kanilang bahay na tinutulyan. Naklipas ang ilang taon, habang si George ay tinuloy ang pag aaral ng medisina. Si primo naman ay nag bago at bumalik sa pag asang magkabalikan sila.Sa aking opinion sinisimbolo ng kanilang bahay ang kanilang estado o kalagayan. May mga bagay na gusto nilang punuin sa bahay na iyon tulad ng malaking 65 inches na TV at sofa, ngunit kalaunan ay hindi nila nagawa. Parang sa relasyon nilang dalawa, may mga bagay na gusto nilang mangyari, mga bagay na pinangarap nilang makamit ngunit hindi nangyari dahil sa sakim na katotohanan ng buhay. Aking nagustuhan sa pelikula ay ang kakayanan nitong ipakita ang hindi makasariling pag-ibig. Pinapakita dito kung paano magmahal ang pagod na puso. Ang mga pangako, panghihinayang, at paghihirap. Kung paano kayang buhusin ng isang tao ang kanyang sarili para sa pagmamahal. Kung paano ito patuloy na tumatayo, subukan man ng mga realidad ng buhay.

“The Hows of Us” is a Filipino movie that depicts the challenges experienced in a long-term relationship such as family dynamics, sacrifice, and resilience. It is centered around two values that all relationships in the Philippines share: tiis (endurance) and alaga (nurturing). The film also emphasizes the desire to go overseas that most in the average Filipino family has. Characters Primo and George embody the passionate, sometimes stubborn, but ultimately kindhearted Filipino dreamer, while George stands for the ate (elder sister) character. The things they say and do depict what real relationships would look like to their fellow countrymen. This is framed by the more serious undertones of what love can mean in the Philippines, which is full of tadhana (fate), enduring love, and personal sacrifice. This film is full of hugot moments, especially when George says: “Dati gusto kitang makasama pangarapin ‘yung mga bagay na gusto natin. Ngayon, gusto na lang kitang makasama kahit wala na ‘yung mga pangarap natin.” That line hits hard because it reflects the painful realization that love sometimes requires letting go of dreams.

The Hows of Us is a heartfelt and realistic portrayal of love, sacrifice, and personal growth in a long-term relationship. The struggles of George and Primo reflect the challenges many Filipino couples face, especially when balancing career aspirations and responsibilities. As a nursing student married to a musician, I can relate to the movie in some ways, particularly in how relationships require understanding and support despite having different paths in life.Filipino culture deeply values resilience and commitment, and this film beautifully captures that. It reminds us that love is not just about staying together but also about growing individually while supporting each other’s dreams. Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla delivered powerful performances, making the story even more relatable and emotionally impactful.This movie highlights that love is not just about passion but also about patience, compromise, and the willingness to face life’s challenges together.

The film “The How’s of Us” (2018), is a romantic drama that explores the struggles of a long-term relationship. The film reflects the ups and downs of love, sacrifice, and personal dreams. It resonated deeply with many of the viewers because of its realistic portrayal of relationships and the challenges young couples face in building a future together. The film highlights how we filipinos are willing to endure hardships for love. George sacrifices a lot for Primo, believing in his potential, even when it hurts her. This reflects the common Filipino trait of matiisin. Also, primo embodies the bahala na attitude, where he follows his dreams despite uncertainty, while George represents the practical mindset of many Filipinos who prioritize stability. This conflict is common in many families and relationships. The how’s of us taught me that love is not just about passion but also about responsibility and growth. It showed that relationships require effort, understanding, and the courage to make difficult choices. The film was emotional and relatable, making me reflect on the importance of balancing dreams and reality.

The Hows of Us (2018) takes a familiar romance-drama formula and injects it with a uniquely Filipino emotional weight. At its core, the film explores the struggles of long-term relationships, the sacrifices made for love, and the inevitable tension between personal dreams and shared commitments.What makes it distinctly Filipino is how it portrays tiis—the kind of endurance that many Filipinos, especially in relationships, hold on to even when things seem hopeless. George (Kathryn Bernardo) and Primo (Daniel Padilla) feel like real people, with George embodying the practical, hardworking Filipina who shoulders more than she should, and Primo representing the dreamer whose ambitions often come at a cost. Their dynamic feels all too familiar, echoing real-life relationships where one partner gives more, hoping the other will eventually change.The film resonates because it doesn’t just rely on hugot lines; it captures the quiet, painful moments of love falling apart. It asks a question that many Filipinos face: When is love no longer enough? And while it gives a hopeful resolution, it never diminishes the emotional toll of staying in a relationship that’s slowly breaking you.It’s a heavy watch, but it’s also a necessary one—reminding us that love isn’t just about how we stay, but why we choose to.

This movie is about love, dreams, and sacrifices. It shows the journey of Primo and George as they struggle to balance their relationship and personal ambitions.It feels very Filipino because it highlights family values, perseverance, and the challenges of love. We can relate to George's situation, where we have to choose between staying in a relationship or prioritizing personal growth. The film "The Hows of Us" depicts love, ambition, and the difficulties of sustaining a long-term relationship in a realistic manner, making it a truly human film. It explores the difficulties of sticking together when dreams conflict and life changes unexpectedly, in contrast with typical romantic romances.The film is relatable because it reflects the true difficulties of commitment via their journey of love, heartbreak, and self-discovery. Additionally, viewers are emotionally moved by the film's themes of sacrifice, resiliency, and the agony of letting go. It portrays relationships as messy, difficult, but worthwhile rather than sugarcoating them. The story feels even more true because of the cultural components, which include pressure to succeed and family expectations. The Hows of Us ultimately captures the unadulterated feelings of love, grief, and personal development, and is more than just a love story.

The Hows of Us feels deeply Filipino in many ways, making it easy for audiences to connect with the story.1. Family Comes First – Unlike Western romances that focus just on the couple, this film highlights how family plays a big role in relationships. George takes care of her younger brother, and Primo struggles with family expectations, showing the Filipino value of utang na loob (debt of gratitude).2. Love, Sacrifice, and Destiny – The movie reflects the Filipino belief in tadhana (destiny) and habambuhay na pag-ibig (lifelong love), where love is worth fighting for despite hardships. George’s patience with Primo and his journey to redemption mirror the sacrifices many Filipinos make for love.3. Familiar Names and Language – George (Georgina) and Primo are names that feel natural in Filipino culture, and the dialogue blends English and Tagalog, just like everyday conversations in the Philippines.4. Authentic Filipino Settings – From traditional homes and Manila’s busy streets to picturesque scenes in Amsterdam, the locations reflect real-life struggles—staying in the Philippines or chasing dreams abroad.5. Dreams vs. Reality – Primo’s passion for music and George’s need for stability represent a common Filipino dilemma: following your dreams or choosing practicality.6. Heartfelt Hugot – The film is packed with emotional lines that hit home, like “Pagod na ako. Kakahintay, kakasalo, kakaisip kung may patutunguhan ba tayo.” These deep, relatable moments make the story even more impactful.Overall, The Hows of Us isn’t just a love story but it’s a reflection of real Filipino relationships, values, and struggles.

“The Hows of Us” is about a couple who have been together for years but are starting to feel the strain of chasing their own dreams while trying to keep their love alive. Watching this movie made me feel a lot of emotions—frustration, sadness, and even a bit of hope. It felt so real, like it was showing a love story that could easily happen to anyone. The idea of sacrificing for love, even when it seems like it’s not working anymore, is something deeply rooted in our culture. Filipinos often hold on to relationships, even when they get difficult, because we value family and long-term commitment so much.This movie made me reflect on love, sacrifice, and the idea that not all relationships are meant to last. Sometimes, people grow apart despite their best efforts, and that’s something everyone can relate to. It’s a bittersweet story, and it hits hard because it feels so familiar.

The film follows George and Primo, a couple who started with big dreams and promises but slowly fell apart due to unbalanced sacrifices and priorities. While the movie tries to capture the highs and lows of love, I didn’t like the way it was portrayed because there could have been a better way to show the struggles of a long-term relationship. Instead of making it about real growth and compromise, it felt like George was the only one making sacrifices while Primo kept making excuses.What made this film distinctly Filipino was how deeply rooted it was in the idea of perseverance in relationships. Many Filipinos are taught to hold on, to be patient, and to fix what is broken instead of walking away. George embodied this—she kept choosing Primo even when he continuously let her down. This is a common theme in hugot films: the painful reality that love alone is not enough.Kathryn Bernardo’s performance as George was incredibly raw and emotional. Her frustration and exhaustion felt so real, especially in that powerful confrontation scene. Meanwhile, Primo’s character was frustrating to watch—he was selfish, immature, and only realized his mistakes when it was almost too late. His actions throughout the film made it clear that George deserved better, and it was exhausting to see her continuously put up with him.One of the most heartbreaking moments in the movie was when George was on her way to take her board exam. She was already in the jeep, finally choosing herself and her future, but she still got off to check on Primo. That moment was painful to watch because it showed how much of herself she had given to him—even when she was about to take one of the most important exams of her life, she still prioritized him. It was frustrating, but it also reflected the reality of many relationships where one person keeps giving while the other keeps taking.Another scene that struck me was when George confronted Primo and said, “Kahit cupcake, hindi mo ako mabigyan.” That line wasn’t just about a cupcake—it was about all the little efforts that Primo never made, the small but meaningful ways he could have shown he cared but never did. It summed up how unreciprocated George’s love and sacrifices had been, and it was heartbreaking to see her reach her breaking point.Some people say romance films feel “sayang” when the leads don’t end up together, but I don’t think that’s always the case. In The Hows of Us, I honestly wouldn’t have minded if George had walked away for good. The emotional damage was already there, and she had given so much of herself without getting anything in return. While the film tries to redeem Primo in the end, it doesn’t erase the fact that George had to suffer before he even realized her worth. The story would have been just as powerful—if not more—if George had chosen herself instead.That being said, I also can’t blame George for acting the way she did. One thing I’ve learned and seen from people around me is that love isn’t universal—everyone experiences it differently. Love can be complex and complicated to the point that it doesn’t make sense to others anymore. Even though I think she deserved better, if she couldn’t see it, then there’s no point. It’s her love, her story, and her choice.This movie made me reflect on love and sacrifice. How much should someone give before realizing they’ve lost themselves? Does love always have to come with suffering? While the film gives hope in the end, it also makes you question whether some relationships are worth holding on to or if letting go is the better choice.

Mahal ko siya, pero hindi ako sapat.The Hows of Us hit too close—too raw—too real. Watching Primo and George fight for their love, I saw a version of myself I once hated: someone who let go, not because I wanted to, but because I thought I had to. Primo’s dreams made him feel unworthy; mine were just excuses to run. Hindi ko matanggap na may taong kayang mahalin ako sa kabila ng lahat ng imperfections ko. So I left before they could change their mind.George stayed and fought. I didn’t.This film isn’t just about love—it’s about timing, self-worth, and the ugly, painful reality that sometimes, the person who loves us the most is the one we push away. Not because we don’t love them back, but because we don’t know how to love ourselves enough to believe we deserve them.And the worst part? Minsan, walang second chance. (pero sana this time, meron na?)

This movie made me wonder, when is the greatest time to fall in love. when is the greatest time to settle and be a fool for someone. my brain is telling me na it’s better pag may naipundar na—may narating. my heart is telling me, mas mabuting maaga. hindi ba ang romantic pag nakasama mo sila lumaki? through ups and downs ika nga. nakakatuwa rin na anjan sila, hindi nasa pundar ng iba. okay lang siguro kung ilalaan nila para sa future sarili nila katulad mo para wala silang babalikan, pero possible na hindi. dapat bang unahan mo na yung iba? hindi ba may mga taong bumabalik talaga sa mga nakakasama nila noong nasa journey sila na katulad ni daniel? nakakatakot kung sarili ko lang mababalikan ko dahil hindi ako nag hangad. o baka naman takot lang akong mapagisa at hindi maranasan yung ganito kaya ako natatakot.after watching this movie, my question remains unanswered. but i realized that i shouldn’t be afraid because there will most likely be many journeys ahead of me—may pipili rin sa sayo. also, bakit ba gustong-gusto kong may angkinin, there must be a reason pero i should fix it. nonetheless, i admire how realistic this movie is.

Pinanood ko ‘tong film na ‘to nung kakabreak pa lang ng (now exes)KathNiel. It felt so real, overwhelming. Ang tanga lang ni Jo for giving up her dreams for a severely drunk Primo but, I would do the same if I were her. Ramdam na ramdam ko yung bawat emosyon sa lines nilang dalawa kaya napaisip ako na “Ah…baka ganito rin sila during that time.” Pero, sino ba ‘ko para magassume sa relasyon ng ibang tao? I relate both to Primo and George. One, being Primo—I saw myself in him as someone who is overly-passionate about what I really love but only to become an unexpected disappointment. Two, being George—George was a realistic character, who stayed, tried to understand the situation despite hindering her from furthering her dreams, still stayed, almost left, left the dream for a man, and left completely—but, she still pursued, hindi pa kasi masiyadong late para magsimula ulit—mahaba ang buhay, do and pursue what you really want to do. Live the most out of the remaining time, you won’t run out of opportunities.

the thing is nakikita naman pala niya kung paano mag-hirap si george pero mas inuuna parin niya ‘yung passion niya. if he really wanted to make it up to her, he should’ve find ways to do so. i don’t know how he wishes na sana hindi sumuko si george when he’s giving her reasons to give up.i’m not invalidating primo’s struggles, it’s hard when something you love (in this case his passion for music) is not working out for you. when you planned your career all your life tapos it doesn’t go the way you wanted it to your whole world will literally fall apart but it doesn’t mean you should stop trying. however, while doing so you should also consider the people around you.well, i guess george’s love for primo is stronger kaya despite everything and how he treated her, she chose to come back to him, but it does not necessarily mean naman na she’s weak or doesn’t know her worth, she just sees that primo became a better person. love is indeed a long journey. so choose the right person to go through that journey with.

yall i think i need to grow up more because the if i were george and primo started singing hanggang kailan to me while playing the guitar i would take him back right away  the movie actually made me cry because as someone fresh out from a 20-month relationship, it’s sad to see the version of someone you once loved dearly fade & suddenly you’re stuck with someone who you don’t seem to recognize anymore BUT ACTUALLY hot take … i think primo deserved a second chance with george  he seemed to have learned his lesson and was actively showing george how he’s changed after years of not beinf in contact. i also think that the vinyl he gave george on her birthday (which she found years after) shows us that he never ignored george’s struggle and was also affected by it as it was a result of his situation. if she only read the letter on the vinyl, i think things would’ve been different actually!! for me, primo was just misunderstood  he wasn’t a red flag (at least for me) but he was just very passionate about something that he has poured his whole life into. not getting your big break after multiple attempts? i would be losing my mind too but anyways! both of them had their faults as characters, george’s being not communicating her feelings to primo (she did this once and it was DONE) and primo… well he has a lot of flaws let’s not dig deeper. but yeah that’s basically itthree stars because the movie made me smile and cry. minus two stars because some of the scenes were a hard watch  and because i just didn’t get the whole “we will go to amsterdam but my dad ends up being dead” plot love can be sweeter the second time around. or maybe the third time around?but i’m never going back to my ex stay safe yall

This confused me on some personal things. As to why should we forgive and still choose the same person who hurt us. How do we forget and still love unconditionally. Looking back at it, George should've not forgiven Primo.But then I found my current partner and understood that in a relationship mistakes are never one sided, both didn't feel assured. They had different priorities but one lacked more and made it difficult to his partner. We used to fight like George and Primo. We would throw things, say things we dislike about each other; cried and despised but still gave us both plenty of chances. We took turns into staying in the living room whenever we fought and thinking about it now makes me laugh. We love each other on our best days and understand us more on our worst. I would sing him "hanggang kailan" that Primo sang to George and just like him, my bf takes care of my family like his own. This movie kind of reminds me of us.

PANGET. Don't waste your time.Ito na yun? I've read wattpad stories with better plot and script honestly. Typical Cathy Garcia writing, puro toxicity nalang at forced positivity.Ito din pala yung movie na kinailangan ni D ng break from showbiz. Jusko, akala ko naman kung anong method acting yung pinakita niya, he was just playing himself. For all i know, they had to add that rain scene kasi hindi siya makaiyak. Jusko, buhat na buhat ni Kath yung movie. "Bakit, hindi ba ako box office king?" Gets ko na yung sinasabi nila na kung wala yan siya sa KN, he wouldn't have been BOK. Tsaka bakit ang daming unnecessary characters and storyline just to make us empathize with the mc. Tapos yung revelation sa ending, wow I've never seen anything like that before. It actually took me to watch two whole movies, several skips and increasing the movie speed into 1.5x just to finish it.Naappreciate ko bigla yung acting ni Alden. At least siya kaya niyang i-match yung acting skills ni Kath. Honestly i was supposed to just give this 1½ stars pero nag-add ako .5 para kay Kath and kay Kath only.

This is one of the most powerful intros for a Filipino movie that I've seen. I was surprised that the highlights and confrontation scenes were shown in the first few minutes, which was a good way to keep the audience engaged throughout the whole movie. On a Tuesday night where I can't go to sleep because it has been quite a day- I went to the Filipino channel and found this movie. I love romcoms with a happy outcome and this one suited me perfect. The love story is elevated above the usual plot although it relies on misunderstandings and withholding information to protect the other. The entire story pivots on a house as a base as an anchor for their love- yet the house provides a way to work out their conflict. I like it. The direction towards the end sort of pushes the audience to a different outlook but as delightful romcoms go- it will please the audience with a sigh- a good sigh and tears will flow. Shhhh- don't tell my wife I'm a softy.
